sub_topic: Time dilation in a moving frame of reference
message_1: A spaceship travels towards a distant star at 0.8 times the speed of light. The round trip will take 8 years according to the people on Earth. How much time will have passed for the astronauts on board the spaceship when they return to Earth?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we need to use the concept of time dilation in special relativity. Time dilation occurs when an object is moving at a significant fraction of the speed of light relative to an observer. The equation for time dilation is:

t' = t / sqrt(1 - v^2/c^2)

where t' is the time experienced by the moving observer (the astronauts), t is the time experienced by the stationary observer (people on Earth), v is the velocity of the moving observer (0.8 times the speed of light), and c is the speed of light.

First, we need to find the time for the one-way trip according to the people on Earth. Since the round trip takes 8 years, the one-way trip takes 4 years.

t = 4 years

Now, we can plug the values into the time dilation equation:

t' = 4 / sqrt(1 - (0.8c)^2/c^2)
t' = 4 / sqrt(1 - 0.64)
t' = 4 / sqrt(0.36)
t' = 4 / 0.6
t' ≈ 6.67 years

Since this is the time for the one-way trip according to the astronauts, the round trip will take twice this amount of time:

Total time for astronauts = 2 * 6.67 years ≈ 13.34 years

So, when the astronauts return to Earth, approximately 13.34 years will have passed for them.
